title: Cost Management – Ultra Detailed Revision Edition
overview: Cost Management (15%) is about accurately measuring and managing the costs of resources, processes, and products. This section covers the full lifecycle: from Cost Concepts (Behavior, Objects) to Systems (Job, Process, ABC), Overhead Management (Allocation, Capacity), and Strategic Improvements (Lean, TOC, Value Chain). Success requires mastering both the calculation of product costs and the strategic analysis of efficiency.
bulletNotes: **Cost Behavior**: Variable (Total varies, Unit constant), Fixed (Total constant, Unit varies), Mixed (High-Low/Regression), Step (Constant in ranges).
**Measurement Methods**: **Actual** (All actual), **Normal** (Actual DM/DL + Budgeted OH), **Standard** (All Standard).
**Absorption vs Variable Costing**: The 'Income Difference' depends on Inventory. Inventory Up = Absorption Income Higher (Fixed OH trapped).
**Process Costing**: **Weighted Average** (Blends BI + Current) vs **FIFO** (Separate BI). EUP calculation is critical.
**Supply Chain & BPI**: **Lean** (Pull/JIT), **TOC** (Bottlenecks), **Value Chain** (R&D to Service), **ABM** (Strategic ABC).

concepts.title: 1. Measurement Concepts & Cost Behavior
concepts.content:
Cost Objects: Anything for which a cost is measured (Product, Dept, Customer).
Direct Costs: Traced economically.
Indirect Costs: Allocated (Overhead).

Cost Behavior:

  • Variable: Total changes w/ volume. Cost/unit constant.
  • Fixed: Total constant. Cost/unit changes inversely.
  • Step: Constant for a range, then jumps.
  • Mixed: Y = a + bX. Separate using High-Low or Regression.

Costing Timing Systems:

  • Actual Costing: Actual DM + Actual DL + Actual OH. (Slow, rarely used).
  • Normal Costing: Actual DM + Actual DL + Allocated OH (based on Budgeted Rate × Actual Activity).
  • Standard Costing: Standard DM + Standard DL + Standard OH. (Best for control).

concepts.title: 2. Absorption vs Variable Costing (The Inventory Effect)
concepts.content:
FeatureAbsorption (GAAP)Variable (Internal)
Product CostsDM + DL + VOH + FOHDM + DL + VOH
Fixed OverheadInventoriable Product CostPeriod Cost (Expensed)
Production > SalesIncome Higher (FOH trapped in End Inv)Income Lower (FOH expensed)
Sales > ProductionIncome Lower (FOH released)Income Higher

Formula: Diff in Income = Change in Inv Units × Fixed OH per Unit

concepts.title: 3. Cost Accumulation Systems
concepts.content:
Job Order Costing: Custom products (Law firm, Construction). Costs tracked by Job. Key: Job Cost Sheet.

Process Costing: Mass production (Oil, Soda). Costs by Dept. Key: Equivalent Units of Production (EUP).

  • Weighted Average: (Beg Cost + Curr Cost) / (Equiv Units). Blends periods.
  • FIFO: Current Cost / Equiv Units. Separates Beg Inv cost. EUP = (BI × % to finish) + Started&Completed + (EI × % complete).

Life-Cycle Costing: Tracks measurement from R&D → Disposal. 80-90% of costs committed in Design phase. Target Costing is often used here (Price - Desired Profit = Target Cost).

concepts.title: 4. Overhead Allocation & Capacity
concepts.content:
Departmental Rates: More accurate than Plant-wide if depts use overhead differently.

Service Dept Allocation:
1. Direct Method: Allocates only to Production Depts. Ignores service-to-service support.
2. Step-Down (Sequential): Allocates one-way (e.g., IT to HR, but not HR to IT). Order matters.
3. Reciprocal: Fully recognizes mutual services (simultaneous equations). Most accurate.

Capacity Levels (Denominator Level):

  • Theoretical: 100% efficiency (Ideal). Avoids under-applied OH but unachievable.
  • Practical: Realistic (includes maintenance). Best for product costing/pricing.
  • Normal: Long-term average (3-5 years). Smooths fluctuations.
  • Master Budget: Expected usage for next period. Can lead to 'Death Spiral' if demand drops (Rate goes up → Price up → Demand down).

concepts.title: 5. Activity-Based Costing (ABC) & Management (ABM)
concepts.content:
ABC: Refines costing by assigning overhead to Activities, then to Objects.

  • Hierarchy: Unit, Batch, Product, Facility.
  • Goal: Fix cross-subsidization (Low-volume complex products are usually under-costed by traditional methods).

Activity-Based Management (ABM): Using ABC data to improve processes. Focus on Value-Added (Customer willing to pay) vs Non-Value Added (Storage, Moving, Rework) activities.

concepts.title: 6. Joint Product & By-Product Costing
concepts.content:
Joint Products: High relativity value, produced together.

  • Split-off Point: Point of separation.
  • Allocation Methods: Physical Measure, Sales Value at Split-off, NRV (Sales - Separable Cost).
  • Decision Rule: Allocation is irrelevant. Process further if Inc Revenue > Inc Cost.

By-Products: Low value. 2 Methods:
1. Production Method: Recognize at production (reduces COGS).
2. Sales Method: Recognize when sold (Other Income).

concepts.title: 7. Supply Chain & Business Process Improvement
concepts.content:
Lean Manufacturing:
Goal: Remove Waste. JIT (Demand Pull, Cell Layout, Kanbans).
Theory of Constraints (TOC):
Focus on Bottleneck. Throughput = Sales - DM (DL/VOH are fixed). Drum-Buffer-Rope.

Value Chain Analysis:
R&D → Design → Supply → Prod → Mktg → Dist → Service.
Strategy: Coordinate all links to add customer value.

Business Process Reengineering (BPR): Radical redesign (clean slate).
Benchmarking: Compare to best-in-class.

ERP (Enterprise Resource Planning): Integrated software suite (Finance, HR, Ops) sharing a central database.

mistakes: Using Master Budget Capacity for fixed overhead rates (can cause Death Spiral).
Allocating Joint Costs for 'Process Further' decisions (Joint costs are Sunk).
Confusing Normal Spoilage (Product Cost) with Abnormal Spoilage (Period Loss).
ignoring the 'Step-Down' order in service allocation.
Using Variable Costing for GAAP/External Reporting (Forbidden).
summary: This Ultra Detailed edition ensures full coverage: from the details of Cost Behavior and Absorption Costing to the strategic nuances of Capacity Levels, Service Department Allocation, and Business Process Improvement. Mastery here means understanding not just 'how to calculate' but 'why it matters' for internal decision-making vs. external reporting stability.

quiz.question: Which capacity level is recommended for calculating fixed overhead rates to avoid the 'death spiral'?
quiz.explanation: Practical Capacity is best because it provides a stable rate that doesn't fluctuate with demand drops (unlike Master Budget) and is achievable (unlike Theoretical). It highlights the cost of unused capacity.

quiz.question: In Service Department Allocation, which method accounts for services provided between service departments in a one-way fashion?
quiz.explanation: The Step-Down (Sequential) method allocates costs one-way (e.g., A to B, but not B back to A). The Direct method ignores all inter-service support. Reciprocal accounts for both ways.

quiz.question: If Beginning Inventory is 0, Production is 10,000 units, and Sales are 8,000 units, how does Absorption Costing income compare to Variable Costing income?
quiz.explanation: Inventory increased (Prod > Sales). Fixed Overhead is 'trapped' in the 2,000 units of Ending Inventory under Absorption Costing, deferring expense and thus increasing current income compared to Variable Costing.

quiz.question: Using the High-Low method, if the cost at 1,000 hours is $5,000 and at 2,000 hours is $8,000, what is the fixed cost?
quiz.explanation: Variable Rate = ($8000 - $5000) / (2000 - 1000) = $3/hr. Total Cost = Fixed + (Rate × Activity). $5000 = Fixed + ($3 × 1000) -> Fixed = $2000.

quiz.question: Which quality cost category includes 'Warranty Repairs'?
quiz.explanation: Warranty repairs happen after the product has reached the customer, making them External Failure costs (the most expensive kind).

essay.question: Compare and contrast the Direct Method and the Reciprocal Method of service department cost allocation. Which is more accurate and why?
essay.modelAnswer:
1. Direct Method:
Allocates service department costs only to production departments. It completely ignores any services provided by one service department to another (e.g., IT support given to HR). It is simplest but least accurate.

2. Reciprocal Method:
Allocates costs by recognizing all mutual services between support departments using simultaneous equations. It reflects the full cost of support.

Conclusion:
The Reciprocal Method is more accurate because it captures the true consumption of resources across the entire organization, whereas the Direct Method may understate the cost of service departments that heavily utilize other support functions.
